sentence.content: Walton is a character it would be difficult to invent, an all-American boy who became one of the world&apost;s most successful businessmen.

sentence.content: The church-going son of a farmer born in 1918 near Kingfisher, Oklahoma, he founded a store chain which made him America&apost;s richest man, and which, shortly before his death in 1992, became the world&apost;s biggest retailer.

sentence.content: His company, Wal-Mart, made sales of Dollars 55bn last year, and after Walton&apost;s death Fortune magazine reported that his wife and four children held between them the second-largest fortune in the world - Dollars 23.5bn.

sentence.content: Sometimes, Walton was more reluctant to invest in technology, and had to be persuaded by colleagues to introduce computers, and scanning at check-outs - long before most retailers had recognised their importance - and to invest Dollars 20m in an internal satellite communications system.

sentence.content: Regional vice-presidents based at group headquarters in Bentonville, Arkansas, rather than in costly regional offices, are despatched every Monday by aircraft to their regions, spend the week visiting stores, working with staff and managers, and return for a day-long merchandising meeting every Friday.
